text:

A yob who tried to punch Crystal Palace defender Damien Delaney has escaped ban from football - despite admitting attack. 
Jack Coles, 23, of Worthing, East Sussex, jumped the barrier and confronted the Irish centre half after watching his side slump to 4-0 at half time to fellow relegation battlers Sunderland at Selhurst Park. 
Coles was frustrated as the Eagles were 'having their worst season ever' and Sunderland had just scored three goals in five minutes. 
Spurred on by chants of 'you're not fit to wear the shirt' from the crowd Coles shoved his chest at Delaney, 35, and attempted to punch him before being restrained by stewards. Coles confronts Delaney (Photo: Rex Features) Read More Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Crystal Palace fans vent anger after Sunderland mauling Share this video Watch Next 
Palace had already confiscated Coles' £500 season ticket but the Croydon Magistrates Court decided to just fine him £180, which was immediately lessened to £120 fro his guilty plea. 
Prosecutor Rahab Njoroge said: "It was Saturday 4 February at approximately 3:50pm when the defendant was seen exiting the spectators stand by jumping the barriers and going onto the football pitch. 
"The defendant than ran towards Damien Delaney, one of the football players, who was leaving the pitch at half time and confronted him in an aggressive manner. 
"He was shoving his chest into Damien Delaney and then attempted to punch him, that is when he was restrained by security staff. Delaney squares up to Coles (Photo: BPI) 
"The defendant was shown CCTV in his police interview and stated that he was watching the game and got frustrated as his team were doing very poorly. 
"He stated 'they have been having their worst season ever'." 
Coles insisted he did not target Delaney - he just took aim at the closest player to him. 
Adrian Butt, defending, said: "It appears the whole crowd were chanting 'you are not fit to wear the shirt'.' 
"It was a passionate moment and he wanted to express that they were playing so badly." 
He admitted to using threatening words or behaviour that could have caused alarm or distress and entering the playing area at a designated football match. 
He was fined £120, ordered to pay costs of £85 and a surcharge of £55 to be taken out of his benefits but was not banned from attending football matches. Like us on Facebook
